raw_comment: This graph is comparing if 15- 24 year old's and 40 and older to think the world is becoming better. Based on the graph -24 year old's are more optimistic then 40 and older's. This makes me wonder if there is some inaccuracy because I don't think people can really concept how the world was when with the older generation. The world is changing so much so fast that it would be hard to determine. Of course, you know major events that happen during history during that time but, if you didn't live through that point in time you can't really know. Also, I'm wondering if the younger people are more optimistic because they have been raised with the internet which gives them more hope and belief that the world will become better. Lastly, do more younger people think the world is becoming better based the economic situation in their country. I also wonder how the graph would look different if you surveyed the 40 and older generation when they were younger and see if their answers would differ. A catchy catch phrase: Countries Optimistic Generation
ace_sentences: The graph compares two age groups.
One age group is 15-24 years old.
One age group is 40 years old or older.
The graph compares whether people think that the world is becoming better.
People who are 15-24 years old are more optimistic than people who are 40 years old or older.
I wonder whether the graph is inaccurate.
I think that young people cannot really understand how the world was in the past.
Because the world changes very fast, it is hard to determine whether the world is becoming better.
A person can know major historical events.
If a person did not live through a time, then the person cannot really know that time.
I wonder whether young people are more optimistic because they were raised with the internet.
The internet can give young people more hope.
The internet can give young people more belief that the world will become better.
I ask whether more young people think that the world is becoming better because of the economic situation in their country.
I wonder how the graph would look if the survey asked people who are 40 years old or older about their opinions when they were younger.
I wonder whether the answers of these people would differ.
The catch phrase is: Countries Optimistic Generation.
